This question asks about our ability to perceive the movement of the sun. Option (A) is the correct answer. It would take approximately half an hour for us to notice the sun's movement across the sky. This is because the movement of the sun is relatively slow and gradual. It moves approximately 15 degrees per hour, and for us to notice this movement, we would need to observe the position of the sun over a period of time. 

Option (B) is incorrect because 15 seconds is too short of a time frame to perceive the sun's movement. Option (C) is also incorrect because half a minute is not long enough to notice the sun's movement. Option (D) is clearly incorrect as one nanosecond is an incredibly short period of time during which we would not be able to perceive any movement.

This question is asking about how long it takes for a person to notice the movement of the sun. The correct answer is (A) half an hour. 

To understand why, we need to consider the speed at which the Earth rotates and the apparent movement of the sun in the sky. The Earth takes approximately 24 hours to complete one full rotation on its axis. This rotation causes the sun to appear to move across the sky.

Since the Earth takes 24 hours to complete a full rotation, this means that it takes 12 hours for the sun to move from the eastern horizon to the western horizon. Therefore, in half an hour, the sun would have moved a small fraction of this distance and it would be difficult for an individual to notice this movement with the naked eye.

Option (B) 15 seconds and option (C) half a minute are both too short of a time frame for a noticeable movement of the sun. Option (D) one nanosecond is an extremely short period of time, far too brief for any noticeable movement to occur. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) half an hour.

This question is asking about the perception of the sun's movement in the sky. To answer this question, we need to consider the speed at which the sun moves and the time it would take for us to notice any noticeable change in its position.

The sun appears to move across the sky due to the rotation of the Earth. The Earth completes one full rotation in approximately 24 hours. This means that the sun appears to move across the sky at a speed of 15 degrees per hour (360 degrees divided by 24 hours).

Given this information, if we were to stand in one spot and watch the sun, it would take approximately 2 hours for the sun to move 30 degrees (15 degrees per hour x 2 hours). Therefore, it would take about 30 minutes for us to notice a noticeable change in the sun's position.
